channel.title: Nature Communications
channel.description:
Nature Communications is an open access, multidisciplinary journal dedicated to publishing high-quality research in all areas of the biological, health, physical, chemical and Earth sciences. Papers published by the journal aim to represent important advances of significance to specialists within each field.

We are committed to providing an efficient service for both authors and readers. Our team of independent editors make rapid and fair publication decisions. Prompt dissemination of accepted papers to a wide readership and beyond is achieved through a programme of continuous online publication.

item.title: SL<InlineEquation ID="IEq1"> <InlineMediaObject> <ImageObject Color="BlackWhite" FileRef="41467_2025_65214_Article_IEq1.gif" Format="GIF" Height="19" Rendition="HTML" Resolution="72" Type="Linedraw" Width="40" /> </InlineMediaObject> <EquationSource Format="TEX">$$(2,{\mathbb{C}})$$</EquationSource> <EquationSource Format="MATHML"><math> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mrow> <mn>2</mn> <mo>,</mo> <mi mathvariant="double-struck">C</mi> </mrow> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> </math></EquationSource> </InlineEquation> non-Abelian gauge fields in a photonic molecule array
item.content:encoded:
Nature Communications, Published online: 19 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-65214-z

Artificial gauge fields offer a powerful tool for engineering the topological phase of matter. Here, the authors propose a scheme to simulate an SL $$(2,{\mathbb{C}})$$ ( 2 , C ) non-Abelian gauge field by coupled photonic molecules in synthetic space-frequency dimensions, which enables various Dirac semimetal transitions.
